definition: SMD jumper wire in resistor form.
Dallas/Maxim single-wire protocol for temperature sensors and device identification with parasitic power option.
Oscilloscope probe with 10:1 attenuation.
The frequency at which a filter's output drops to 70.7% of its passband value, corresponding to half power.
An industrial signaling standard where sensor readings are encoded as current between 4 mA (zero) and 20 mA (full scale), immune to wire resistance errors.
Family of CMOS logic ICs operating from 3-18 V, offering low power and wide supply range; common in industrial and legacy designs.
Family of TTL and CMOS digital ICs providing basic gates, flip-flops, counters, and other building blocks, introduced in 1966.
High-speed CMOS logic family, pin-compatible with 7400-series TTL but with CMOS power and threshold characteristics.
High-speed CMOS logic with TTL-compatible input thresholds; accepts 3.3 V inputs when powered from 5 V.
Family of fixed positive linear voltage regulators (7805 = 5 V, 7812 = 12 V, etc.); standard in legacy power supplies.
Family of fixed negative linear voltage regulators (7905, 7912, 7915); complement to the 78xx positive regulators.
Line code mapping 8-bit data to 10-bit symbols for DC balance and clock recovery; 25% bandwidth overhead.
Frequency-weighting curve approximating human hearing sensitivity at moderate listening levels, attenuating low and high frequencies while emphasizing 1–6 kHz.
SPICE frequency-sweep simulation showing gain and phase response across a range of frequencies.
Signal path that blocks DC and passes only the time-varying component.
Transmission line termination using a series capacitor and resistor, providing correct impedance at signal frequencies while blocking DC current draw.
Aircraft Communications Addressing and Reporting System; text messaging protocol between aircraft and ground stations.
Running a product at elevated stress levels to simulate years of aging in weeks.
The timing error that builds up over many clock cycles, measured as the deviation of the Nth edge from its ideal position.
How close a measurement reading is to the true value.
Acute-angle copper feature on a PCB where etchant can pool during fabrication, potentially under-etching the copper.
A filter using op-amps or other active devices to shape frequency response without inductors.
Oscilloscope probe with a built-in amplifier at the tip, presenting very low capacitance (~1 pF) and high impedance.
Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast; system where aircraft transmit position and identification on 1090 MHz.
Professional balanced digital audio interface using 110-ohm twisted pair with biphase mark encoding.
Automatic Gain Control — a feedback loop that adjusts gain to maintain constant output amplitude.
Logarithmic capacitance loss over time in Class II and III ceramic capacitors due to dielectric relaxation.
Primary bus interconnect on ARM Cortex-M MCUs connecting CPU, memory, and high-speed peripherals.
Automatic Identification System; maritime protocol where ships broadcast identification and position on VHF.
Unwanted lower-frequency components appearing in a sampled signal when it contains frequencies above the Nyquist frequency.
SI unit of electric current.
A logic gate that outputs 1 only when all inputs are 1.
Frequency expressed in radians per second: ω = 2πf.
Width of copper pad surrounding a drilled PCB via hole, critical for reliable electrical connection.
Ratio of radiated power to input power; determined by radiation resistance divided by total resistance.
Directivity of an antenna multiplied by its efficiency; measured in dBi (relative to isotropic) or dBd (relative to dipole).
A low-pass filter before an ADC that prevents frequencies above half the sample rate from folding back as false signals.
The clearance hole in a ground or power plane around a via that is not connected to that plane.
Automated Optical Inspection; machine vision system comparing assembled PCB images to a reference to detect defects.
Secondary peripheral buses (APB1, APB2) on ARM Cortex-M MCUs connecting lower-speed peripherals like UART, SPI, and timers.
Variation in the exact sampling moment of an ADC, introducing timing errors that translate to amplitude errors.
Making stencil openings smaller than pad size to reduce solder paste volume and prevent bridging on fine-pitch components.
The finite time a sample-and-hold circuit takes to acquire the signal; introduces error proportional to signal slew rate.
The product of RMS voltage and RMS current, measured in volt-amperes (VA).
Vendor document explaining design methodology for a component family, including equations and tradeoff guidance.
Automatic Picture Transmission; analog image format broadcast by NOAA weather satellites at 137 MHz.
GCC cross-compiler for ARM bare-metal targets using the Embedded ABI, the standard Cortex-M toolchain.
A FIFO buffer with independent read and write clocks for cross-domain data transfer.
Circuit that resamples digital audio from one clock domain to another, decoupling source and destination clocks to reject jitter.
Property of an operation that completes in a single uninterruptible step at the hardware level.
A dedicated test instrument for measuring audio performance metrics including THD, THD+N, SNR, frequency response, and crosstalk.
Audible click, pop, or silence caused by a DSP block missing its real-time processing deadline.
Logarithmic potentiometer resistance curve that matches human loudness perception; required for volume controls.
Instrument feature that automatically selects the measurement range.
Non-destructive reverse breakdown in a diode where carrier multiplication occurs at high electric field.
Atmel/Microchip 8-bit RISC microcontroller core with true Harvard architecture and 32 registers. Used in the Arduino Uno (ATmega328P) and ATtiny series.
For circularly polarized antennas, the ratio of major to minor axis of the polarization ellipse.
Electromagnetic principle stating that a slot in a conducting surface is the complement of a strip conductor of the same shape.
Removing unused via stub portions on thick PCBs by drilling from the opposite side, reducing signal reflections.
A wire terminal that has slipped partially out of its connector housing, appearing connected but making intermittent or no electrical contact.
Building automation protocol using RS-485 for HVAC, lighting, and access control communication between controllers.
A transmission path where both signal conductors have equal impedance to ground, enabling common-mode rejection through symmetry.
Transformer or transmission-line device converting between balanced and unbalanced systems; may also perform impedance transformation.
A filter that passes frequencies between low and high cutoff points and attenuates outside that range.
A filter that attenuates a specific range of frequencies while passing those above and below.
A reference circuit exploiting complementary temperature coefficients to produce a temperature-stable output near 1.25 V.
Intentional undersampling of a narrowband signal to alias it to a lower frequency; requires a bandpass anti-alias filter.
An oscilloscope setting that engages a low-pass filter (typically 20 MHz) to reduce high-frequency noise on the displayed waveform.
The reduction in overall bandwidth when identical amplifier stages are cascaded.
Embedded firmware that runs without an operating system, managing all scheduling and resource allocation directly.
The condition for sustained oscillation: loop gain ≥ 1 and total phase shift = 360°.
The original frequency range of a signal before modulation; contrasted with the modulated carrier frequency.
Cortex-M register that selectively disables interrupts below a configured priority level while allowing higher-priority interrupts.
The data rate of a serial interface in bits per second.
Bulk acoustic wave filter using piezoelectric resonators, providing sharp selectivity at GHz frequencies.
Controlling phase and amplitude of signals to multiple antenna elements to steer the radiation pattern.
Angular width of an antenna's main lobe, typically measured at -3 dB half-power points.
Production test fixture using spring-loaded pogo pins contacting PCB test pads for automated electrical verification.
Filter response with the best phase linearity and minimal step-response overshoot.
The DC current gain of a BJT, defined as I_C / I_B, varying widely between devices.
IC package with solder balls on the bottom surface instead of pins on the perimeter.
ARM heterogeneous multi-core architecture pairing high-performance cores (e.g., Cortex-A76) with power-efficient cores (e.g., Cortex-A55) on one SoC.
Method for converting an analog filter design to a digital IIR filter, preserving magnitude response but warping the frequency axis.
Self-clocking line code with a transition at every bit boundary and a mid-bit transition for 1s; used in AES/EBU and S/PDIF.
Symmetrical positive and negative supply voltages (e.g., +/-35 V) used to power audio amplifier output stages.
Second-order IIR filter section with 5 coefficients, commonly cascaded to build complex digital filters.
Serial clock in I2S/TDM that clocks each individual bit; rate equals sample rate times bits per sample times channels.
Memory access technique on Cortex-M3/M4 where each bit in a peripheral or SRAM region is aliased to a full 32-bit word for atomic bit manipulation.
The binary configuration file that programs an FPGA.
A bipolar junction transistor — a current-controlled device where small base current controls large collector current.
Window function with -58 dB sidelobes and wide main lobe; used when spectral dynamic range matters more than frequency resolution.
Bluetooth Low Energy; low-duty-cycle wireless protocol for sensors, beacons, and IoT, introduced in Bluetooth 4.0.
BLE broadcast mode where a device transmits presence packets at configurable intervals before connection.
A resistor placed across a capacitor to safely discharge stored energy when power is removed.
DSP approach where samples are collected into fixed-size frames and processed as a group, trading latency for efficiency.
A two-panel graph showing magnitude (dB) and phase (degrees) versus frequency on a logarithmic scale.
A jumper wire added to a PCB after assembly to correct a design error, add a missing connection, or repair a broken trace.
The parasitic diode between source and drain in a MOSFET, conducting when drain voltage drops below source.
Bill of Materials — the list of every component, quantity, and reference designator needed to build a PCB assembly.
Switching power supply topology that produces an output voltage higher than its input.
Immutable mask ROM in an SoC that runs first at power-on, loading the initial bootloader from boot media.
Small program stored in protected flash that receives, validates, and installs new firmware images for field updates.
Technique using a capacitor to raise the effective impedance of a bias network by feeding back the output signal, increasing gain.
JTAG-based test method (IEEE 1149.1) that verifies IC solder connections by toggling and reading I/O pins through the scan chain.
Block RAM — dedicated dual-port SRAM blocks in FPGAs.
A path between two nodes in a circuit, carrying a single current.
A four-diode configuration that converts AC to DC by conducting both polarities through two diodes each.
Amplifier configuration where two channels drive opposite ends of a load, doubling the voltage swing and quadrupling the power into the load.
Hardware circuit that monitors supply voltage and asserts reset if it drops below a configured threshold, preventing corrupted execution.
Board Support Package; vendor-supplied software bundle including bootloader, kernel, drivers, and configuration for a specific board.
Bit Set/Reset Register on STM32 GPIOs enabling atomic single-bit pin operations without read-modify-write.
Standard bidirectional level-translation circuit using a BSS138 N-channel MOSFET with pull-ups on both voltage domains.
Switching power supply topology that produces an output voltage lower than its input.
Switching topology that can produce an output voltage either higher or lower than the input, with inverted polarity in the basic form.
Build system generating minimal embedded Linux images from source for custom hardware.
USB transfer type for large non-time-critical data with error recovery; used by CDC serial and mass storage.
Voltage drop across an ammeter's internal shunt resistor.
A fault condition where two or more drivers simultaneously assert conflicting levels on a shared bus, causing excess current and indeterminate logic levels.
CAN error state where accumulated errors exceed 255, completely disconnecting the node from the bus.
Cortex-M exception on failed bus transactions: unclocked peripherals, unmapped memory, or invalid DMA addresses.
Analog filter with maximally flat passband response; the default choice when predictable amplitude behavior is desired.
Filter response with maximally flat passband and monotonic roll-off.
Capacitor placed near an IC's power pins to supply instantaneous current demands and shunt high-frequency noise to ground.
Class I ceramic dielectric.
The problem of maintaining consistent data between CPU caches and DMA controllers or other bus masters that access DRAM directly, bypassing the cache.
The physical location where VNA calibration standards are connected, defining the measurement reference point.
Message-based differential bus protocol for reliable multi-node communication in noisy environments, using CRC and automatic retransmission.
Extension of classic CAN allowing higher data-phase bit rates (up to 8 Mbps) and larger payloads (up to 64 bytes).
Hardware transmit or receive buffer in the CAN peripheral, with priority-based arbitration by message ID.
IC converting MCU-level CAN_TX/CAN_RX signals to differential CAN_H/CAN_L bus levels and vice versa.
Industrial CAN application protocol defining PDOs, SDOs, NMT, and standard device profiles for automation equipment.
Horizontal conductor at an antenna tip that increases end capacitance, improving radiation resistance and efficiency.
Gradual evaporation of the liquid electrolyte in an electrolytic capacitor, causing ESR to rise and capacitance to drop over time, especially at elevated temperatures.
Gradually applying voltage to an old or long-stored electrolytic capacitor to rebuild its oxide dielectric layer before full operation.
Vintage resistor type made from a solid slug of carbon and binder.
A fast adder technique computing all carries in parallel instead of rippling through stages.
FM bandwidth approximation: BW ≈ 2 × (Δf + f_m), capturing about 98% of the FM signal power.
A two-transistor configuration combining common-emitter with common-base to improve bandwidth and output impedance.
IEC 61010 measurement category indicating the transient voltage environment an instrument is rated for, from CAT I (low energy) to CAT IV (utility entrance).
Resonant mode inside an enclosed conductive volume, with frequency determined by the cavity dimensions.
Core Coupled Memory on some STM32 MCUs connected directly to CPU, not accessible by DMA, used for time-critical code.
Clock Domain Crossing — a signal passing between circuits driven by different clocks.
Assembly data file listing each component's reference designator, X/Y coordinates, rotation, and board side for pick-and-place.
Piezoelectric bandpass filter using ceramic resonators, common at IF frequencies in consumer receivers.
Configurable Fault Status Register on Cortex-M3+, combining MemManage, BusFault, and UsageFault status bits.
The impedance of a transmission line determined by its geometry and dielectric.
Transient voltage disturbance caused by capacitive coupling from the gate when a MOSFET switch toggles.
A voltage converter using switched capacitors instead of inductors, simpler but lower power than inductor-based converters.
Electrical connection to the equipment's metal chassis or frame.
Filter response with steeper roll-off than Butterworth at the cost of passband ripple.
Miniature ceramic surface-mount antenna for PCB integration, trading efficiency for size.
Amplifier that modulates a DC signal to AC, amplifies in a 1/f-noise-free region, then demodulates; achieves microvolt offset.
Fundamental physical limit stating that antenna size, bandwidth, and efficiency cannot all be maximized simultaneously.
Cascaded Integrator-Comb filter; efficient decimation/interpolation filter using only additions and subtractions, no multipliers.
Periodic convolution computed by the FFT; differs from linear convolution and causes wrap-around artifacts unless zero-padded.
Three-port device directing RF energy from one port to the next in sequence; used for transmit/receive isolation.
Protection component (typically a diode or TVS) that limits voltage excursions by conducting when a threshold is exceeded.
Using a diode and capacitor to shift the DC level of an AC signal without changing its shape.
Variant of the Colpitts oscillator with improved frequency stability via an additional series capacitor in the tank.
Bias scheme for push-pull output stages that keeps a small idle current flowing to eliminate crossover distortion.
Switching audio amplifier using PWM or PDM output stage at 85-95% efficiency; transistors operate fully on or off.
Using diodes or other components to limit signal excursion by conducting when a threshold is exceeded.
Dedicated chip that generates multiple synchronized clock outputs from a single reference with low added jitter.
The difference in clock arrival time between two points in a system.
An I2C feature where a slave device holds the clock line (SCL) low to pause communication while it processes data.
A balanced distribution network of buffers ensuring equal clock delay to all flip-flops.
The propagation delay from a clock edge to when the flip-flop output changes.
The gain of a circuit with feedback applied, approximately 1/β when loop gain is large.
Contiguous Memory Allocator; Linux kernel mechanism reserving physically contiguous RAM at boot for DMA buffers.
A logic family built from complementary NMOS and PMOS transistor pairs, now dominant in digital design.
ARM standard providing unified header files and runtime libraries for Cortex-M peripherals across different vendors.
ARM's open-standard debug probe protocol; any vendor can implement it for SWD/JTAG debugging.
Rounding of digital filter coefficients to fixed-point representation; can shift poles and zeros, degrading IIR filters.
Setting a test signal frequency to fall exactly on an FFT bin center to eliminate spectral leakage without windowing.
Correction applied to thermocouple measurements to account for the temperature of the measurement junction (cold junction) not being at 0 degrees C.
A solder connection that did not properly reflow, appearing dull or grainy and causing intermittent high resistance.
Negative feedback resistor from collector to base that stabilizes the DC operating point against transistor beta variations.
Vertically stacked half-wave elements fed in phase to increase gain in the horizontal plane.
LC oscillator using a capacitive voltage divider for feedback, common in VHF/UHF applications.
A BJT amplifier with input at the emitter and output at the collector, providing current gain and high bandwidth.
A BJT amplifier configuration with input at the base and output at the collector, providing voltage gain with phase inversion.
A MOSFET amplifier with input at the source and output at the drain, analogous to common base.
A MOSFET amplifier with input at the gate and output at the drain, analogous to common emitter.
An inductor with two windings on a shared core that presents high impedance to common-mode current while passing differential-mode signal through unimpeded.
Noise voltage that appears equally on both signal conductors relative to ground, often from ground loops or radiated pickup.
An instrument's or amplifier's ability to ignore voltage that appears equally on both inputs.
The average voltage on two conductors relative to ground: V_cm = (V(A) + V(B)) / 2. Noise that shifts both conductors equally is common-mode.
A circuit that compares two voltages and outputs a binary high or low result.
Inductor core made from magnetic particles suspended in resin.
Input power level at which device gain drops 1 dB from linear; indicates onset of nonlinear behavior.
SoC + DRAM on a small board with edge connector, designed to plug into a custom carrier board for production use.
Microphone using a charged capacitive element; requires bias voltage or phantom power, typically higher output than dynamic mics.
Electromagnetic interference that travels along wires and cables rather than through the air.
Resilient conductive material used at enclosure seams to maintain RF shielding while allowing mechanical assembly.
Protective polymer layer applied over assembled PCBs to guard against moisture, dust, and contamination.
Impedance match where source and load impedances are complex conjugates, maximizing power transfer.
Solvent spray that removes oxidation and contamination from electrical contacts and connector pins to restore reliable connections.
Gradual wear of relay or switch contact surfaces from arcing and mechanical abrasion, leading to increased resistance or welding.
Heavy-duty relay rated for switching high-power loads such as motors and heaters, with arc suppression contacts.
Saving one task's CPU registers and stack pointer and loading another's, essential for RTOS multitasking.
PCB traces designed with specific dimensions relative to the ground plane to achieve a target characteristic impedance.
The standard engineering convention: current flows from positive to negative.
Power loss through a passive mixer, typically 5-8 dB for diode ring mixers.
Task scheduling where each task voluntarily yields by returning; no preemption, requires disciplined task design.
Transmission line with signal trace and ground conductors on the same PCB plane.
Large area of copper on a PCB layer, typically connected to ground or power.
PCB copper thickness specified in oz/ft-squared; 1 oz equals 35 um, determining current capacity and trace width limits.
FR4 laminate with a copper layer bonded to one or both sides, used as substrate for PCBs and prototyping ground planes.
The frequency below which flicker noise exceeds white noise in a device's noise spectrum.
ARM application processor core family designed for throughput and OS support, featuring out-of-order execution, deep pipelines, caches, and an MMU.
ARM's family of 32-bit processor cores designed for microcontroller use, including M0, M0+, M3, M4, and M7 variants.
SI unit of electric charge.
A register that increments or decrements its value on each clock cycle.
A set of conductors beneath or around an antenna serving as a ground reference, typically radial wires.
Capacitor in series with a signal path that passes AC while blocking DC.
In a directional coupler, the ratio of coupled port power to input power in dB.
SPI Clock Phase — determines whether data is sampled on the leading (0) or trailing (1) clock edge.
Complex Programmable Logic Device — multiple PLD blocks connected by a programmable routing matrix.
SPI Clock Polarity — determines the idle state of the SPI clock line (0 = idle low, 1 = idle high).
Error detection code computed over data to verify integrity in communication, firmware images, and stored configuration.
Minimum PCB distances required for safety isolation; creepage is along surfaces, clearance is through air.
Ratio of peak to RMS amplitude; varies by waveform and determines headroom requirements.
The longest propagation delay path between flip-flops, limiting maximum clock frequency.
Compiling code on a host machine that produces binaries for a different target architecture.
Signal loss when the transmit and receive antennas have different polarization orientations.
Distortion in push-pull output stages caused by both transistors being off near the signal's zero crossing.
Unintended signal coupling between adjacent conductors through parasitic capacitance or mutual inductance.
A quartz crystal vibrating at a precise frequency, used as a clock source.
Coefficient of thermal expansion; rate at which a material's dimensions change with temperature, measured in ppm/°C.
Temperature above which a ferroelectric ceramic's dielectric properties degrade sharply.
A probe that measures current by sensing the magnetic field around a conductor without breaking the circuit.
Ratio of optocoupler output current to input LED current; degrades over time as the internal LED dims from aging.
First applying power through a current-limited bench supply after repair, so that a remaining short draws only the set limit instead of causing cascading damage.
Dedicated IC that measures voltage across a shunt resistor and outputs a ground-referenced signal proportional to current flow.
High-speed DAC using matched current sources steered to output or dummy load by differential switches.
A PCB trace intentionally severed, usually as a rework modification.
The frequency at which a filter's response is 3 dB below the passband level.
The difference in duration between two adjacent clock periods, capturing short-term timing variation.
An edge-triggered memory element that captures D input on a clock edge and holds it.
A latch controlled by a data input and enable signal, transparent when enable is active.
Displayed Average Noise Level — noise floor of a spectrum analyzer at a given resolution bandwidth.
Two cascaded transistors giving very high current gain; trades voltage headroom (two V_BE drops) for input sensitivity.
Deterministic jitter caused by bandwidth limitations and intersymbol interference on clock/data paths.
25-pin D-subminiature connector used for RS-232 serial and PC parallel ports in legacy systems.
9-pin D-subminiature connector commonly used for RS-232 serial ports on PCs and test equipment.
De facto standard file format describing CAN message layouts: signal positions, scaling factors, and units.
Decibels relative to a half-wave dipole, a common reference for antenna gain measurements.
Decibels Full Scale — reference scale in digital audio where 0 dBFS represents the maximum representable digital value.
Decibels relative to an isotropic radiator, the standard reference for absolute antenna gain.
Power measured in decibels referenced to 1 milliwatt.
Voltage in decibels referenced to 0.775 V (the voltage that produces 1 mW into 600 Ω).
Voltage in decibels referenced to 1 volt.
Reduction in ceramic capacitor effective capacitance when DC voltage is applied, especially severe in X7R and Y5V.
Loss of capacitance in ceramic capacitors when DC voltage is applied.
Setting the DC operating point of an active device to ensure it operates in the correct region for signal amplification.
Signal path that passes all frequencies including DC.
Unwanted DC voltage present at an amplifier output that should be at zero volts with no signal applied; excessive DC offset can damage speakers or downstream loads.
SPICE analysis solving for steady-state voltages and currents at every node with specified supply voltages applied.
Data Communications Equipment; in RS-232, the device that transmits on pin 2 and receives on pin 3.
The resistance of an inductor's winding measured at DC.
Discrete Cosine Transform — real-valued transform used in audio and image compression, more energy-compacting than DFT.
The complement of AND is OR with complemented inputs, and vice versa.
Mathematically removing cable, connector, and fixture effects from a measurement to isolate the device under test.
Receiver-side high-frequency attenuation that complements transmitter pre-emphasis, equalizing FM noise spectrum for improved SNR.
Linker optimization that discards unreferenced functions and data sections, saving flash space.
The interval between turning off one switch and turning on the complementary switch in a bridge circuit to prevent shoot-through.
Prototyping method where ICs are soldered upside-down on a copper ground plane with point-to-point wire connections.
Hardware delay between one half-bridge output turning off and the complementary output turning on, preventing shoot-through.
Condition where two or more tasks each hold a resource the other needs, causing all to block permanently.
Capacitor in hot-chassis equipment between mains and chassis that, if it shorts, puts lethal mains voltage on the enclosure.
Technique for stabilizing noisy digital inputs by sampling multiple times and recognizing transitions only after consistent state.
ARM CoreSight interface providing halt, inspect, and modify access to CPU state through JTAG or SWD.
Reducing sample rate by filtering and downsampling; removes high-frequency content and reduces data rate.
A combinational circuit that activates one of 2^n outputs based on an n-bit input code.
Placing capacitors near IC power pins to supply instantaneous switching current and prevent noise from propagating through the power distribution network.
Separation of PCB laminate layers caused by excessive heat, moisture absorption, or mechanical stress, compromising board structural and electrical integrity.
Difference in propagation time between first-arriving and last significant signal component; causes frequency-selective fading.
Oversampling converter using a noise-shaping feedback loop and digital decimation to achieve high resolution at moderate output rates.
Mathematical technique for converting between triangle (delta) and star (wye) resistor network topologies.
Virtual memory technique where physical pages are allocated only when first accessed, triggering a page fault.
A voltage or current source whose value is controlled by another voltage or current elsewhere in the circuit.
A MOSFET that is normally on, conducting with zero gate voltage.
Reducing a component's maximum allowable power, voltage, or current as operating conditions (typically temperature) move away from the rated conditions.
Spring-loaded vacuum tool that sucks molten solder from through-hole joints, used for component removal.
Property that execution meets timing deadlines predictably; hard real-time requires deterministic worst-case behavior.
Jitter with identifiable causes and bounded amplitude, including data-dependent, periodic, and duty-cycle distortion components.
A data structure (.dts/.dtb) that describes hardware to the Linux kernel — peripheral addresses, interrupt wiring, pin configuration — without requiring kernel recompilation.
Compiled binary describing SoC and board hardware, passed to the Linux kernel at boot for device discovery.
Patch modifying the base device tree at boot to enable add-on hardware like HATs or capes.
Design for Assembly; layout practices that simplify and improve component placement and soldering reliability.
Design for Manufacturing; practice of making layout decisions that satisfy PCB fabrication process constraints and improve yield.
Discrete Fourier Transform; converts N time-domain samples into N frequency-domain values; the FFT is an efficient algorithm for computing it.
Design for Test; building measurement access points and debug features into a circuit from the start of schematic design.
Direct Injection box — an audio device using a transformer or active circuit to convert unbalanced high-impedance signals to balanced low-impedance, breaking ground loops.
Insulating material between capacitor plates that determines capacitance, voltage rating, stability, and loss characteristics.
The tendency of a capacitor to recover a portion of its charge after being briefly discharged, also called soakback.
Property of an insulating material affecting electromagnetic wave speed and impedance; also called relative permittivity.
Shift in resonant frequency caused by nearby dielectric material slowing electromagnetic wave velocity.
Op-amp circuit that outputs the amplified difference between two input voltages; converts differential signals to single-ended.
Two matched transistors with tied emitters/sources and a common current source, the fundamental building block of analog ICs.
An oscilloscope probe that measures the voltage difference between two points, neither of which needs to be ground.
Signal transmission using two conductors carrying equal and opposite voltages; the receiver measures only the difference, rejecting noise that appears equally on both.
Noise voltage that appears between the two signal conductors, indistinguishable from the wanted signal and harder to filter without affecting the signal.
Bending of electromagnetic waves around obstacles or edges; more pronounced at lower frequencies.
Hard distortion when a digital signal reaches 0 dBFS; samples clamp with no gradual onset, producing harsh odd harmonics.
Return path for digital logic circuits, separated from analog ground to prevent switching noise coupling.
IC using capacitive or magnetic coupling to transfer digital signals across a galvanic isolation barrier without LED degradation.
A series incandescent light bulb wired inline with a power input that limits fault current and provides a visual indicator — glows brightly if the DUT is shorted.
DMM test mode that forward-biases a junction and displays the voltage drop, used to verify transistor junctions and identify shorted or open semiconductor devices.
Passive mixer using four matched diodes in a ring, providing good linearity and no DC power requirement.
DMM mode that forces a small current through a semiconductor junction and displays the forward voltage drop, useful for checking diodes and BJT junctions.
Device separating or combining signals of different frequency ranges into shared ports.
SDR architecture that digitizes the RF signal directly without analog frequency conversion.
Transmission line component sampling a fraction of signal power from the main path for monitoring.
Ratio of antenna radiation intensity in the maximum direction to that of an isotropic source.
Wideband omnidirectional antenna shaped like a disc over a cone, commonly used for scanning receivers.
The maximum number a DMM can show on its display (e.g., 6000 counts for a 3 3/4-digit meter), determining resolution on each range.
A circuit element whose physical dimensions are significant relative to a wavelength, requiring transmission line analysis.
Intentionally added noise before quantization that randomizes quantization error, converting distortion into perceptually preferable noise.
Adding small noise before quantization to randomize rounding error, converting audible distortion into benign broadband noise.
Fault isolation strategy that splits the signal chain at a midpoint and tests each half, halving the search space with each measurement.
Hardware engine that moves data between peripherals and memory without CPU intervention, essential for high-throughput applications.
DMA request multiplexer allowing flexible mapping of any peripheral DMA request to any DMA channel.
The fundamental bench instrument for measuring voltage, current, and resistance.
Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages; formal discipline for managing component obsolescence in long-life systems.
Serial lighting control protocol using RS-485 physical layer to address up to 512 dimmer or fixture channels.
Differential Non-Linearity — variation in ADC/DAC step size between adjacent codes; DNL > 1 LSB means missing codes.
Adding a low-frequency pole to ensure gain drops below unity before phase accumulates to 360°.
Change in signal frequency due to relative motion between transmitter and receiver.
Dots placed on transformer winding symbols to indicate which terminals have the same instantaneous polarity.
Technique using two alternating buffers so one fills with new data while the other is processed, enabling continuous real-time streaming.
Mixer topology rejecting both LO and RF feedthrough, providing superior port isolation.
Technique for soldering fine-pitch IC pins by dragging a fluxed, lightly tinned iron tip across the row of pins, relying on surface tension to keep solder on the pads.
The amount of current a logic output can source or sink.
The minimum input-to-output voltage difference required for a regulator to maintain regulation.
Double Sideband Suppressed Carrier; AM variant transmitting both sidebands but no carrier, requiring coherent demodulation.
Dedicated multiply-accumulate hardware in FPGAs for signal processing.
Data Terminal Equipment; in RS-232, the device that transmits on pin 3 and receives on pin 2.
PCB layout technique placing overlapping or adjacent pads for two package options at the same component position.
MCU flash organized as two independent banks, enabling firmware update of one bank while executing from the other.
A resistive load that substitutes for the real load (such as a speaker) during bench testing, providing a known, stable impedance for repeatable measurements.
Device allowing simultaneous transmission and reception on the same antenna by separating frequency bands.
Device Under Test — the circuit, board, or component being debugged, measured, or verified.
The fraction of time the main switch is on in a switching regulator, determining the voltage conversion ratio.
Clock jitter from asymmetry between rising and falling edge timing, causing unequal high and low periods.
Data Watchpoint and Trace unit on Cortex-M providing watchpoints and cycle counting for debug and profiling.
Microphone generating signal through electromagnetic induction; needs 40-60 dB of clean gain, no phantom power.
Ratio between the largest undistorted signal and the smallest detectable signal, accounting for noise floor and clipping.
The slope of the I-V curve at a specific operating point (dV/dI).
The slight increase in BJT collector current with higher V_CE, caused by base-width modulation.
A BJT parameter (V_A) representing the extrapolated voltage at which collector current would become zero.
Physical connection to the earth, typically through the building's grounding system.
Engineering Change Order; formal process for proposing, reviewing, approving, and documenting a design modification.
Power dissipated by circulating currents induced in a conductive core by the changing magnetic field.
