Distortion products at 3rd, 5th, 7th multiples of the fundamental; sound harsher, characteristic of semiconductor clipping.
SI unit of electrical resistance.
The fundamental relationship between voltage, current, and resistance.
Output Third-Order Intercept Point — theoretical output level where third-order intermodulation equals fundamental.
On-off keying; the simplest digital modulation where the carrier is switched on and off to represent binary data.
Linux kernel mechanism that terminates processes when physical memory is exhausted and no swap is available.
An operational amplifier — a high-gain differential amplifier used as a universal analog building block with external feedback.
The voltage measured across a source's terminals when no load is connected.
A logic output with only a pull-down transistor, requiring an external pull-up for the HIGH level.
GPIO mode where the pin can only pull LOW actively and floats HIGH, requiring an external pull-up resistor.
The gain of an op-amp without feedback, typically 100,000 V/V or more at DC.
The nominal signal level a stage is designed to handle, balancing SNR above the noise floor and headroom below clipping.
Non-volatile configuration bits controlling MCU behavior such as brownout threshold, debug access, and flash protection.
A logic gate that outputs 1 when any input is 1.
Coupling device between the circuit under test and the oscilloscope input.
Over-The-Air wireless firmware update allowing field devices to receive new firmware without physical connection.
The impedance a circuit presents at its output terminals.
AC voltage variation superimposed on the DC output of a switching regulator.
Current flow exceeding a component's or circuit's rated maximum, typically caused by a short circuit, excessive load, or failed protection device.
Block processing method that sums zero-padded, convolved segments to produce continuous output from overlapping blocks.
Block processing method that discards corrupted edge samples from circular convolution to produce correct linear convolution output.
UART/SPI error when new data arrives before firmware reads the previous byte, silently losing data.
Sampling at a rate much higher than Nyquist; spreads quantization noise across wider bandwidth and enables noise shaping.
Ratio of actual sample rate to the minimum Nyquist rate; higher OSR relaxes analog filter requirements and enables noise shaping.
RF signal attenuation near 60 GHz caused by molecular oxygen resonance in the atmosphere.
Exception raised when the CPU accesses a virtual address with no valid mapping in the page table. The kernel handles it by allocating a page, loading data, or killing the process.
Vintage capacitor using paper dielectric impregnated with oil; absorbs moisture over decades and develops DC leakage.
Components connected across the same two nodes so that they share the same voltage.
PC I/O interface (DB-25/LPT) repurposed for digital control; provides 8 data, 5 status, and 4 control TTL-level lines.
Transmission line termination with a resistor matching the line impedance at the receiver end, absorbing the signal to prevent reflections.
A component degradation where the part still functions but operates outside its specified parameters, often caused by ESD or thermal stress.
Unintended capacitance present between conductors, component leads, PCB traces, and other structures.
Unintended inductance in component leads, wires, and PCB traces.
Technique where a 1-Wire device draws operating power from the data line via an internal diode and capacitor.
Unintended partial powering of an IC through its ESD clamp diodes when an external signal is applied while the supply is off.
Optimal equiripple method for FIR filter design minimizing maximum error in passband and stopband.
The series transistor in a linear regulator whose resistance adjusts to maintain constant output voltage.
The frequency range where a filter passes signals with minimal attenuation, ideally with flat response.
Amplitude variation within a filter's passband, characteristic of Chebyshev and elliptic designs; measured in dB.
Planar antenna with a conductor on a dielectric substrate over a ground plane; compact and easy to fabricate.
Signal attenuation during propagation including free-space spreading, absorption, and scattering.
The arrangement of copper layers, dielectric materials, and thicknesses defining a printed circuit board's electrical and physical properties.
Pulse Code Modulation — standard digital audio encoding where samples are quantized to discrete levels.
Pulse Density Modulation — encoding analog information as pulse density in a bitstream; output of 1-bit delta-sigma modulators.
Power Distribution Network — the complete power delivery path from regulator to transistors.
Packet Error Checking; optional CRC-8 byte appended to SMBus transactions for data integrity verification.
Cortex-M exception used for deferring processing to lower priority, commonly used by RTOS for context switching.
The deviation of any single clock period from the ideal period, measured as a standard deviation or peak-to-peak value.
Deterministic jitter from supply noise or crosstalk at specific frequencies; appears as discrete sidebands in phase noise plots.
Mechanism enabling or disabling individual peripheral clocks to save power; peripheral registers are inaccessible while gated.
Pulse frequency modulation — a light-load operating mode where switching frequency reduces to maintain efficiency.
48 V DC supplied to condenser microphones through balanced audio cables; not needed for dynamic microphones.
The stability margin — difference between actual phase and 360° at the frequency where loop gain equals unity.
Random fluctuations in oscillator phase; expressed in dBc/Hz at a specific offset frequency.
Antenna array with electronically controlled phase per element to steer the beam without mechanical movement.
Three-element matching network with two shunt and one series reactive component, offering adjustable Q.
Automated machine that picks components from reels or trays and places them onto solder-paste-coated PCB pads before reflow.
Crystal oscillator circuit commonly used in digital ICs, using a crystal between inverter input and output.
Generation of voltage from mechanical stress in certain materials.
Diode with thick intrinsic region behaving as a variable resistor controlled by bias current; used in RF switches.
The functional label of an IC pin (e.g., CLK, RESET, VCC).
The physical location identifier of an IC pin on the package.
Components sharing identical package outline and pinout, allowing PCB-level substitution without layout changes.
Assembly technique printing solder paste into through-hole component holes and reflowing to eliminate a separate wave-solder step.
Multi-stage converter where each stage resolves a few bits and passes the residue; achieves high throughput with pipeline latency.
The FPGA design step assigning logic to physical locations and connecting them.
Programmable Logic Controller; industrial computer that replaced relay logic for machine control and process automation.
Phase-Locked Loop — a feedback circuit synchronizing output frequency with a reference.
Power Management IC — manages multiple voltage rails, power sequencing, and power-good signaling for complex SoCs requiring carefully ordered supply bringup.
The directional convention for voltage measurement.
Orientation of the electric field in an electromagnetic wave; can be linear, circular, or elliptical.
A frequency in a transfer function that contributes -20 dB/decade roll-off and up to -90° of phase shift.
A resettable overcurrent protection device (PTC thermistor) that increases resistance when tripped and resets when power is removed.
A connection point in a hierarchical schematic that links a sub-sheet to the level above.
Feedback where the returned signal reinforces the input, causing output to diverge. Used in oscillators and latches.
Circuit simulation incorporating parasitic elements extracted from the actual PCB layout for improved accuracy.
A structured write-up documenting a debugging session's symptom, root cause, misleading hypotheses, fix, and lessons learned for future pattern recognition.
Capturing crash data in non-volatile memory so fault information survives reset for later analysis.
A three-terminal variable resistor with an adjustable wiper contact.
Inductor core made from iron particles with insulating gaps between them.
High-output-power RF amplifier; often nonlinear (Class C, D) for efficiency.
An accounting of all power sources, conversions, and dissipation in a system.
Reduction in a component's maximum allowable power dissipation at temperatures above a specified threshold.
The ratio of real power to apparent power.
Schematic symbols (VCC, VDD, 3V3, 5V, GND) representing global power connections.
Return path for high-current circuits such as switching regulators and motor drivers.
The maximum continuous power a component can dissipate at a specified ambient temperature without exceeding its maximum operating temperature.
The required order and timing of multiple supply rails powering up and down, critical for multi-rail systems to avoid latchup or damage.
Normalized spectral power per unit bandwidth (V²/Hz); independent of FFT length.
A digital output from a voltage regulator indicating that its output has reached and is within regulation limits.
Hardware reset generated when supply voltage rises through its threshold at initial power-up. SRAM contents are undefined after POR.
A measure of ratio.
High-frequency signal boost at the transmitter to compensate for channel attenuation.
First active amplification stage in a signal chain, critical for establishing system noise performance.
The consistency of repeated measurements.
Linux kernel patch set that converts most spinlocks to sleeping mutexes and makes interrupt handlers schedulable, reducing worst-case latency from milliseconds to tens of microseconds.
A counter used to divide a clock frequency by a fixed amount.
Bandpass filter before an RF amplifier to reject out-of-band signals.
Cortex-M register that disables all configurable interrupts when set; BASEPRI is more selective.
Concurrency protocol where a mutex is assigned the priority of its highest-priority potential user, preventing nested inversion.
An encoder that outputs the binary code of the highest-priority active input.
RTOS mechanism that temporarily raises a mutex holder's priority to match the highest-priority blocked waiter.
RTOS pathology where a low-priority task holding a resource blocks a high-priority task while medium-priority tasks run.
Adjusting a passive oscilloscope probe's trimmer capacitor so its RC time constant matches the scope input, producing a flat frequency response.
The distortion introduced by a measurement probe's input impedance (resistive and capacitive) on the circuit being measured.
Formal manufacturer document announcing changes to a component including discontinuation or process changes.
Fieldbus protocol for industrial automation running on RS-485, widely used in European process control and factory automation.
The time for a signal to travel from one point to another, approximately 6-7 ns per meter on FR4 PCB traces.
Speed at which an electromagnetic wave travels through a medium, always less than or equal to c.
A self-protection state in power amplifiers triggered by DC offset, overcurrent, short circuit, or overtemperature, shutting down outputs to prevent damage.
Oscilloscope or logic analyzer feature that interprets captured waveforms as bus transactions (I2C addresses, SPI bytes, UART frames, etc.).
Redistribution of current in adjacent conductors due to mutual magnetic fields, increasing effective resistance at high frequencies.
Programmable Real-time Unit — deterministic 200 MHz co-processor on TI Sitara SoCs (BeagleBone) providing single-cycle, guaranteed-timing I/O alongside Linux.
A component whose resistance increases with temperature.
A resistor connected to supply voltage to establish the HIGH level for open-drain outputs.
Encoding technique where information is carried in the timing of pulse edges rather than pulse width or density.
Complementary transistor pair that alternately sources and sinks current to the load, used in most power amplifier outputs.
Pulse-Width Modulation — generating analog-like output by toggling a digital pin with variable duty cycle at fixed frequency.
The DC operating point of a transistor, determined by the bias circuit.
Quadrifilar helix antenna producing circular polarization, commonly used for weather satellite reception.
Quad Flat No-lead — an IC package with exposed pads on the bottom instead of visible side leads, requiring hot air or reflow for rework.
Quad Flat Package — an IC package with fine-pitch leads on all four sides, common for microcontrollers and interface chips.
Frequency conversion using two mixers with 90-degree LO phase offset to produce I and Q signal components.
A measure of how selective a resonant circuit or filter is, with higher Q meaning narrower bandwidth.
Signal-correlated error at small amplitudes where quantization error is no longer random; sounds harsh and metallic.
Difference between the actual analog value and the nearest quantized level.
Quantization error treated as additive noise when signals are large enough to randomize the error.
Transmission line section of specific impedance and quarter-wavelength used to transform impedance between two values.
The current drawn by a circuit when no signal is applied and no load is driven.
DAC resistor network using only two resistor values to produce binary-weighted output currents; simple, monotonic by design.
The on-resistance of a MOSFET when fully enhanced, a key parameter for switching efficiency.
Concurrency bug where outcome depends on timing of access to shared data across execution contexts.
Low-power design strategy: run the MCU at full speed to complete work quickly, then enter deep sleep. More energy-efficient than running continuously at a slow clock.
Electromagnetic interference that propagates through the air as electromagnetic waves from a circuit or cable.
Plot of relative field strength or power radiated by an antenna in all directions.
Equivalent resistance representing power radiated by an antenna.
Maximum line-of-sight distance for radio propagation, slightly beyond the geometric horizon due to atmospheric refraction.
Drop in a power supply rail voltage under heavy load, caused by the supply's limited current capacity or resistive losses in the distribution path.
An op-amp whose output can swing close to both supply rails, typically within 50-200 mV.
Signal attenuation at microwave and mmWave frequencies caused by absorption and scattering from raindrops.
Jitter with a Gaussian distribution caused by thermal noise and shot noise, unbounded in theory and characterized by RMS value.
Priority assignment where tasks with shorter periods get higher priority; well-studied for periodic task sets.
Small-scale fading where multipath components cause rapid signal variation following a Rayleigh distribution.
Series resistor-capacitor network placed across relay contacts or switches to suppress arcing and conducted EMI transients.
Process of removing old solder balls from a BGA package and attaching new ones using solder paste or preforms before re-mounting the IC.
Power that cycles back and forth between source and reactive components (capacitors, inductors) without performing net work.
Register access sequence that is not atomic on shared registers and can lose updates if interrupted.
The power actually dissipated as heat or converted to useful work, measured in watts.
Meeting timing deadlines predictably — not necessarily fast, but deterministic and bounded-latency.
Wholesale replacement of all electrolytic capacitors in vintage equipment to restore reliability after age-related degradation.
The minimum input signal power at which a receiver can achieve a specified performance level.
Principle that an antenna's radiation pattern and impedance are the same whether transmitting or receiving.
Analog low-pass filter removing spectral images in DAC output, converting the staircase to smooth analog.
The implicit window when no windowing function is applied, providing the best frequency resolution but the worst spectral leakage.
Vendor-provided schematic and layout demonstrating tested component usage, intended as a starting point for custom designs.
The unique identifier for each component on a schematic and PCB: R1, C2, U3, Q4, etc.
The assumed direction of current flow or voltage polarity assigned during circuit analysis.
The node assigned zero volts in nodal analysis.
Complex number describing reflected wave magnitude and phase; Γ = (Z_L - Z₀) / (Z_L + Z₀).
Temperature-versus-time curve a PCB follows through a reflow oven, with preheat, soak, peak reflow, and cooling phases.
Assembly process where solder paste is heated through a controlled temperature profile to form joints on all pads simultaneously.
A group of flip-flops sharing a common clock, storing a multi-bit word.
Verifying that a repair or change did not introduce new faults in previously working functions or adjacent circuits.
How well a voltage source maintains its output under varying load conditions.
A DMM mode that stores a reference reading and displays subsequent measurements as the difference from that reference, useful for zeroing out lead resistance.
Control system built from electromechanical relays wired to implement AND, OR, latching, and timing functions; precursor to PLCs.
Address in the vector table where the CPU begins execution after reset.
The smallest change in a measured quantity that an instrument can display.
Width of the IF filter in a spectrum analyzer that determines the minimum frequency separation between resolved signals.
The frequency at which an LC circuit oscillates with maximum amplitude.
Loss in dB of reflected signal power; higher return loss indicates better impedance matching.
RF Wheatstone bridge circuit that measures scalar return loss by comparing a DUT to a 50-ohm reference.
The conductor carrying current back to the source to complete the signal loop. Not synonymous with ground — it is a physical path with impedance that affects signal quality.
Using a series or parallel diode to block current if the supply is connected backwards.
The time during which a forward-conducting diode continues to conduct briefly in reverse while stored charge is swept out.
Manual modifications to a PCB after assembly: bodge wires, component swaps, cut traces.
Lossy material placed inside enclosures to damp cavity resonances.
Right-hand circular polarization; the electric field vector rotates clockwise as viewed from behind the wave.
Damped oscillation in a step response, indicating marginal stability or underdamped poles.
AC current superimposed on DC current flowing through a capacitor.
Open instruction set architecture with modular extensions, growing rapidly as an alternative to ARM.
The time for an output to transition from 10% to 90% of its final value in response to a step input.
Reduced Media Independent Interface; pin-reduced parallel bus connecting an Ethernet MAC to a PHY on MCU boards.
The effective value of a time-varying signal.
Low-loss PCB substrate with tightly controlled dielectric constant, standard for RF designs above a few gigahertz.
Parameter K used to assess unconditional stability of a two-port RF device; K > 1 indicates stability.
Remote Processor Messaging framework for inter-processor communication between Linux A-cores and bare-metal M-cores.
A UART electrical standard using ±3 to ±15 V signal levels.
A differential serial standard supporting multi-drop networks over long distances.
Register Transfer Level — the abstraction level describing data storage and movement between registers.
Inexpensive software-defined radio dongle based on RTL2832U chip covering 24 MHz to 1.8 GHz.
Real-Time Operating System providing preemptive multitasking, scheduling, and synchronization primitives.
Real-Time Transfer; Segger protocol for high-speed logging via shared SRAM buffer and debug probe, without halting the CPU.
Transmission-line balun with a single winding, providing narrower bandwidth but simpler construction than Guanella.
Scattering parameters measured by network analyzers describing how RF energy scatters at device ports.
Sony/Philips Digital Interface — consumer digital audio interface carrying PCM on coaxial or optical connection.
Heavy-duty vehicle CAN protocol using 29-bit extended IDs at 250 kbps with standardized parameter groups.
The most common active filter topology, using a single op-amp in non-inverting configuration.
Circuit that samples an analog signal and holds the value during conversion; fundamental ADC operation.
Successive Approximation Register ADC using binary search to converge on input voltage; fast and common in MCUs.
The current at which an inductor's core can no longer store additional magnetic energy, causing inductance to drop.
The BJT operating region where both junctions are forward biased and the transistor acts as a low-impedance switch.
Surface Acoustic Wave filter using acoustic waves on a piezoelectric substrate; compact, used up to 3 GHz.
Single-Board Computer — a complete Linux-capable system on one PCB: SoC, DRAM, storage interface, power regulation, and I/O connectors.
Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition; system for remote monitoring and control of industrial processes and infrastructure.
DMA transfer mode that reads from or writes to non-contiguous physical memory pages described by a list of address/length pairs, solving the virtual memory fragmentation problem.
Linux real-time scheduling policy where the highest-priority runnable thread always gets the CPU with no time-slicing.
A diode with a metal-semiconductor junction exhibiting lower forward voltage and faster switching than conventional junction diodes.
A permanent test point (often a BNC jack) wired across a circuit node to allow easy, repeatable oscilloscope connection without clip leads.
Standard Commands for Programmable Instruments — an ASCII command syntax for remote control of test equipment over GPIB, USB, or LAN.
Software-Defined Radio — radio system where filtering and demodulation traditionally done in hardware is performed in software.
A destructive failure mode where localized heating causes current focusing in high-voltage BJTs.
Practice of qualifying at least two interchangeable component options from different manufacturers to reduce supply chain risk.
Automated soldering process targeting individual through-hole joints on an otherwise SMD-assembled board.
Receiver's ability to reject signals outside the desired frequency range.
An automated internal calibration routine in an instrument that corrects for drift using built-in references, distinct from traceable external calibration.
Power dissipation within a component raising its own temperature, changing its electrical parameters.
The frequency at which a capacitor's ESL resonates with its capacitance, causing impedance to reach a minimum.
RTOS synchronization primitive — binary semaphores signal events, counting semaphores track available resources.
Debug mechanism allowing target MCU to call host-side functions via breakpoint; slow but useful for development.
A low-value precision resistor placed in a current path so that the voltage drop across it indicates the current flowing.
Minimum signal level a receiver can detect and process with acceptable performance.
A non-inverting buck-boost topology producing output voltage above or below input with same polarity.
Serializer-deserializer — dedicated high-speed transceiver blocks for multi-gigabit communication.
Components connected end-to-end so that the same current flows through each.
A resistor at the driver matching line impedance to prevent reflections.
The minimum time data must be stable before the clock edge for reliable capture.
Spurious-Free Dynamic Range — ratio between the signal and largest spurious component.
Ratio of a filter's bandwidth at high attenuation to its 3 dB bandwidth, indicating transition sharpness.
A metal enclosure soldered to a PCB ground plane that contains or excludes electromagnetic fields around sensitive circuitry.
Inductor with a magnetic structure that contains the magnetic field, reducing radiated interference and susceptibility to external fields.
Attenuation in dB that an enclosure provides against electromagnetic fields passing through its walls.
A register where data moves one position per clock cycle through cascaded flip-flops.
Two-dimensional pass/fail map testing a circuit across two variables simultaneously to visualize operating region boundaries.
Bridge driver fault where both switches are ON simultaneously, shorting the supply rail; prevented by dead-time insertion.
The current that flows when a source's output terminals are connected together.
Random noise caused by the discrete nature of charge carriers crossing a barrier, proportional to DC current.
A two-terminal voltage reference that sinks current to maintain a fixed voltage.
Low-value resistor used inside ammeters and current-sense circuits to convert current into a measurable voltage.
Standard multipliers for units: tera (10¹²), giga (10⁹), mega (10⁶), kilo (10³), milli (10⁻³), micro (10⁻⁶), nano (10⁻⁹), pico (10⁻¹²), femto (10⁻¹⁵).
New frequency component created by modulation, offset from the carrier by the modulating frequency.
Signal Metadata Format; a standard for describing recorded I/Q data including sample rate, frequency, and type.
Block diagram showing each processing stage, its gain, and the signal level at each point in a multistage chain.
The reference point for signal voltages in a circuit.
Introducing a known test signal at a point in the circuit and checking whether it appears correctly at subsequent stages.
The quality of an electrical signal on a transmission path, encompassing reflections, crosstalk, attenuation, and timing degradation.
Following a signal through successive stages of a circuit with an oscilloscope or probe to locate where it is lost, distorted, or stuck.
Psychoacoustic effect where a loud tone makes quieter tones at nearby frequencies inaudible.
Signal-to-Noise-and-Distortion ratio — the most comprehensive single metric for converter performance.
High-frequency rolloff in a DAC's zero-order hold output caused by the sinc-shaped frequency response.
sin(pi*t)/(pi*t); the ideal interpolation kernel for reconstructing a bandlimited signal from its samples.
Signal transmission where one conductor carries the signal voltage referenced to a shared ground. Simple and cheap, but any noise on the ground adds directly to the signal.
Printed circuit board with copper traces on one side only, using jumper wires where traces must cross; standard in older designs.
Depth at which current density falls to 1/e (37%) of the surface value in a conductor carrying AC.
High-frequency phenomenon where current flows only in a thin surface layer of a conductor.
Long-distance HF radio propagation via ionospheric reflection, enabling beyond-line-of-sight communication.
The difference between required and actual signal arrival time; positive means constraint is met.
The maximum rate at which an op-amp output can change voltage, typically expressed in V/µs.
Antenna formed by a narrow slot cut in a ground plane; the complementary of a dipole via Babinet's principle.
Linear circuit analysis describing device response to small AC signals around a DC operating point.
System Management Bus; I2C variant with stricter timing, clock timeout, and optional CRC for power management ICs.
Three or four digit code: for a 3-digit code, the first two digits are significant and the third is the exponent.
Graphical tool mapping complex impedance to reflection coefficient for matching network design.
First controlled power application to a new board using current-limited supply to detect shorts and faults.
Signal-to-noise ratio — the ratio of signal power to noise power, usually in decibels.
An RC or RCD network that absorbs energy from switching transients, reducing voltage spikes and ringing.
Safe Operating Area — the I-V region where a transistor can safely operate without exceeding voltage, current, or power limits.
System on Chip — a single die integrating CPU core(s), memory controller, GPU, and various peripheral controllers. The CPU is one block among many.
System where a missed deadline degrades quality but does not cause failure; the system keeps running.
A circuit feature that gradually ramps output voltage during startup to limit inrush current.
Nordic's pre-compiled BLE stack binary running as a privileged layer on nRF52 SoCs alongside application firmware.
Debug breakpoint replacing an instruction with BKPT; requires writable memory, rarely usable in flash.
Small Outline Integrated Circuit — a surface-mount IC package with gull-wing leads on two sides, common for 8- to 28-pin devices.
An unintended solder connection between two adjacent pads or traces, creating a short circuit.
Strip of solder mask between adjacent PCB pads preventing solder paste from bridging during reflow assembly.
Thin metal sheet with laser-cut apertures used to deposit precise solder paste volumes onto PCB pads before reflow.
Braided copper strip that removes solder from pads and joints by capillary action when heated with a soldering iron.
Short-Open-Load-Through VNA calibration procedure that removes cable and connector effects from measurements.
The process of "turning off" independent sources to find equivalent resistance: voltage sources become short circuits; current sources become open circuits.
A source resistor in a MOSFET amplifier providing stabilizing feedback, analogous to emitter degeneration.
A MOSFET buffer with unity voltage gain and low output impedance, also called common drain.
A single frequency slot in a DFT/FFT output, representing energy at a specific frequency with resolution f_s / N.
Energy spread across frequency bins when a signal's frequency doesn't fall exactly on a bin center.
Time-frequency representation showing how spectral content changes over time.
Test instrument displaying signal power versus frequency for RF troubleshooting and characterization.
Small capacitor across a base resistor that improves switching speed by providing extra base charge during transitions.
Serial Peripheral Interface — a synchronous, full-duplex, master-slave serial bus.
Synchronous full-duplex multi-slave bus where master drives clock; CPOL and CPHA settings must match between devices.
Secondary Program Loader; first-stage bootloader running from internal SRAM that initializes DRAM before loading U-Boot.
The simplest memory element from two cross-coupled gates with Set and Reset inputs.
Static RAM used for runtime variables, stack, and heap on MCUs; volatile, no refresh required, typically 4–256 KB.
Single Sideband; AM variant transmitting only one sideband for half the bandwidth; used in HF radio communications.
Simultaneous Switching Output — number of pins switching at once, affecting power integrity.
STMicroelectronics debug probe bundled on STM32 Nucleo and Discovery boards for SWD programming and debugging.
Static Timing Analysis — automated timing verification by analyzing all paths without simulation.
Locus on the Smith chart showing source or load impedances that cause an RF device to oscillate.
Condition where the stack grows past its allocated region into adjacent memory, causing silent corruption without default fault.
Debug technique filling the stack with a known pattern at startup and checking for overwrites to detect overflow.
A stationary pattern of voltage maxima and minima on a transmission line caused by interference between forward and reflected waves.
A grounding topology where all ground connections meet at a single point to avoid ground loops and shared-impedance coupling.
Assembly routine running before main() that loads the vector table, copies .data, zeros .bss, and initializes clocks.
Timing conflict where the MCU attempts to communicate with external peripherals before they finish initializing.
A condition where the output should remain constant but momentarily produces the opposite value.
Solder paste stencil with different thicknesses in different areas to accommodate both fine-pitch and large-pad components.
A voltage source with low output impedance, meaning its voltage barely changes when load current varies.
A ground via placed near a signal via on a multilayer PCB to provide a low-impedance return current path when a signal transitions between layers.
The frequency range where a filter provides its specified minimum attenuation, rejecting unwanted signals.
The delay caused by excess base charge that must be removed before a saturated BJT can turn off.
A PCB trace between two ground planes providing controlled impedance and field containment.
Exponential drain current below threshold voltage in a MOSFET, exploited in ultra-low-power design.
Replacing a suspect component with a known-good equivalent to determine if the original was faulty — a quick but destructive-to-undo test for soldered parts.
Very high-capacitance component (farads to hundreds of farads) used for energy storage and extended holdup time.
Receiver architecture using mixers to downconvert RF to intermediate frequencies for easier filtering.
Simple main loop polling sensors, updating state, and driving outputs in fixed sequence without interrupts or RTOS.
In mesh analysis, a combined loop formed when a current source appears in a branch shared by two meshes.
In nodal analysis, a boundary drawn around a voltage source and its two adjacent nodes, allowing KCL to be applied to the combined region.
The principle that in a linear circuit, the total response equals the sum of the responses due to each independent source acting alone.
Dedicated chip monitoring VCC and holding the MCU in reset until supply voltage is stable above a defined threshold.
2-wire debug interface replacing JTAG on Cortex-M with same functionality and fewer pins.
The highest-noise node in a switching regulator, at the junction between the switch and inductor.
Optional third SWD wire carrying trace output from ITM and ETM.
A counter where all flip-flops are clocked simultaneously.
Converting an HDL description into a netlist of logic elements.
Linux virtual filesystem at /sys exposing device attributes as simple files for shell-level hardware control.
Controlled transition from user space to kernel space for requesting OS services like file I/O or device access.
A consistent, repeatable measurement error in the same direction that does not reduce with averaging, caused by calibration offset or method bias.
Built-in 24-bit Cortex-M timer generating periodic interrupts, commonly used as RTOS tick source.
A flip-flop that toggles its output when T input is 1.
Three-element matching network with two series and one shunt reactive component.
State machine where transitions are defined in a data table of (state, event, next-state, action) tuples.
Pogo-pin debug connector system requiring only PCB pads with no through-hole header, saving board space.
NVIC optimization on Cortex-M where consecutive pending interrupts skip the context unstacking/restacking, reducing back-to-back interrupt overhead.
A resonant LC circuit that stores energy by oscillating between the electric field of the capacitor and the magnetic field of the inductor.
Polarized capacitor with high volumetric efficiency.
RTOS data structure storing a task's state, priority, stack pointer, and scheduling metadata.
Temperature-Compensated Crystal Oscillator — a crystal oscillator with active compensation circuitry achieving frequency stability around 1-2 ppm.
Time Division Multiplexing — extension of I2S for multiple audio channels sharing a single serial data line.
Time Domain Reflectometry — measurement using short pulses to characterize transmission lines and locate discontinuities.
Coupled differential equations describing voltage and current on a transmission line; foundation of transmission line theory.
The change in a component's value per degree Celsius, usually expressed in ppm/°C.
Psychoacoustic effect where a loud sound masks quieter sounds occurring just before and after it.
Dedicated accessible pad or loop on a PCB for probing a signal during debug and production testing.
Non-synthesizable HDL code that drives a design with stimulus and checks outputs.
Total Harmonic Distortion — ratio of harmonic distortion power to fundamental signal power.
Total Harmonic Distortion plus Noise — combined measure of all signal degradations.
Imaging device that maps surface temperatures across a PCB or system.
Heat transfer between physically adjacent components.
Solder joint fracture caused by repeated expansion and contraction from temperature changes in power components.
Temperature variation across a PCB causing different components to operate at different temperatures.
Material filling the air gap between a heat-generating component and its heatsink to reduce thermal resistance.
Interface material applied between a component and heatsink to fill microscopic air gaps and reduce thermal resistance.
Spoke-pattern pad connection to a copper plane reducing heat sinking during soldering while maintaining electrical contact.
Resistance to heat flow, analogous to electrical resistance.
A positive feedback loop where increased temperature causes increased current (or power), which further increases temperature.
A protection circuit that disables a device if junction temperature exceeds a safe limit.
Extended-duration test running a circuit in a warm environment to reveal marginal solder joints, failing capacitors, or components that degrade when hot.
Extended-duration powered test revealing marginal thermal, electrical, or mechanical issues that short tests miss.
Automatic clock speed reduction when an SoC reaches its thermal limit, silently lowering sustained performance.
PCB via placed under a component thermal pad to conduct heat from the surface to inner copper planes for spreading.
kT/q, approximately 26 mV at room temperature, appearing throughout semiconductor equations.
A small DC voltage generated at junctions of dissimilar metals (Seebeck effect), creating microvolt-level offsets in precision DC measurements.
Encoding where each increasing value activates one additional element; reduces glitch energy in segmented DACs.
Total thermal resistance from IC junction to ambient air, used to estimate operating junction temperature.
Thermal resistance from IC junction to case or exposed thermal pad; a fixed package property.
Transmission line termination using a voltage divider (pull-up and pull-down resistors) to bias the line to a mid-level voltage while providing the correct impedance.
The most common SMD resistor type.
Precision SMD resistor with tight tolerance (0.1% or better), excellent tempco, and low noise.
Marking system where the first two digits are significant and the third is a power-of-ten multiplier in picofarads.
Any linear circuit reduced to a voltage source (V_th) in series with a resistance (R_th).
On-chip SRAM with single-cycle, deterministic access on Cortex-M7, bypassing caches for predictable timing.
The characteristic response time of an RC or RL circuit.
Relay with a built-in time delay; on-delay and off-delay variants provide sequencing in relay logic control circuits.
The iterative process of modifying a design until all timing constraints are met.
Conductive crystalline filament that grows from pure tin surfaces over time, capable of shorting adjacent pins or traces.
Portable open-source USB device and host stack supporting many MCU families and device classes.
Oscilloscope probing method using the probe tip and barrel ground spring instead of the long ground clip, minimizing ground loop area for high-frequency measurements.
Translation Lookaside Buffer — a small, fast cache of recent virtual-to-physical address translations, avoiding the cost of a full page table walk on most memory accesses.
The allowable deviation of a component's actual value from its nominal value, expressed as a percentage.
The accumulated uncertainty when multiple components' tolerances combine in a circuit.
SMD soldering defect where a two-terminal component stands up on one end due to uneven solder paste reflow, leaving one pad unconnected.
Reading a multi-byte value that was partially updated by another context, yielding a half-old, half-new result.
Optical digital audio interface using LED/photodiode coupling; immune to ground loops.
Standard file format (.s1p, .s2p) for exchanging S-parameter data between simulation and measurement tools.
Triangular Probability Density Function dither with ±1 LSB peak; completely eliminates quantization distortion.
Trace Port Interface Unit; serializes ITM and ETM trace data for output through SWO or a parallel trace port.
Calibration performed against standards with documented accuracy linked back to a national metrology institute through an unbroken chain of comparisons.
The ratio of output current change to input voltage change, a key gain parameter for transistors.
A plot of output versus input (often displayed using XY mode on an oscilloscope) showing the gain and linearity of an amplifier or circuit.
The mathematical ratio of output to input as a function of frequency, fully describing a linear circuit's behavior.
A brief, fast-changing voltage or current event.
SPICE time-domain simulation showing circuit response to changing inputs, startup behavior, and switching waveforms.
Frequency range between a filter's passband edge and stopband edge where attenuation increases.
Frequency at which a transistor's current gain drops to unity; key parameter for determining amplifier bandwidth.
A conductor pair with distributed L and C causing reflection and wave effects at high frequencies.
Oscilloscope feature that synchronizes the display to a specific event on the waveform, producing a stable, readable display.
Small adjustable resistor mounted on a PCB for calibration or bias adjustment; common in legacy circuits needing precision.
The MOSFET operating region where it behaves as a voltage-controlled resistor.
A measurement method that computes the actual root-mean-square value of an AC waveform, giving correct readings for non-sinusoidal signals unlike average-responding meters.
Rounding toward zero when reducing bit depth; creates a DC offset in quantization error unlike symmetric rounding.
A table listing every input combination and corresponding output for a logic function.
Thin-Shrink Small Outline Package — a narrower, thinner variant of SOIC with finer lead pitch.
Transistor-Transistor Logic — a logic family built from bipolar transistors.
A transient voltage suppressor diode designed to absorb large transient energy pulses with well-defined clamping voltage.
Two insulated conductors twisted together at a controlled rate so that external noise couples equally to both, enabling common-mode rejection without shielding.
Two flip-flops in series for safely synchronizing signals between clock domains.
A chromel-alumel thermocouple covering -200 to +1260 degrees C, the most common general-purpose thermocouple type.
The dominant open-source bootloader for embedded Linux. Initializes DRAM, loads kernel and device tree from storage, and provides a serial console for debugging.
Early monolithic op-amp IC (1968) that made operational amplifiers cheap enough for widespread use in analog design.
Universal Asynchronous Receiver-Transmitter — an asynchronous serial interface without a dedicated clock.
Point-to-point asynchronous serial interface with no shared clock, standard for debug consoles.
A transmission path where one conductor is the signal and the other is a shared ground reference; vulnerable to ground noise.
The boundary of stability in the z-plane; IIR filter poles inside are stable, poles on or outside cause oscillation.
Power factor of 1, meaning voltage and current are perfectly in phase.
Inductor with an open magnetic path that allows the magnetic field to radiate.
Cortex-M exception for illegal instructions, unaligned access, division by zero, or disabled coprocessor use.
USB Communications Device Class making an MCU appear as a virtual serial port to the host computer.
Structured data table describing a USB device's identity, class, endpoints, and capabilities to the host.
Addressable data buffer in the USB peripheral for sending or receiving packets in a specific transfer direction.
Host-driven process of discovering and configuring a USB device through control transfers and descriptor exchange.
USB Human Interface Device class for keyboards, mice, and custom reports; requires no driver installation on major OSes.
Module that provides galvanic isolation on the USB data and power lines to break ground loops between host and device.
On-The-Go; USB mode where a single peripheral can operate as either host or device, negotiating role at connection.
Physical layer transceiver handling USB electrical signaling; on-chip for full speed, often external for high speed.
Unprivileged execution environment where applications run, accessing hardware only through system calls.
V-shaped groove partially cut through a PCB panel, allowing individual boards to be snapped apart after assembly.
Collector-emitter saturation voltage of a BJT when fully on; determines conduction loss in switching applications.
A diode whose junction capacitance varies with reverse voltage, used for frequency tuning and modulation.
Voltage Controlled Oscillator — output frequency controlled by input voltage.
Voltage-controlled crystal oscillator that allows small frequency adjustments via an applied voltage.
Array of 32-bit addresses at the start of flash containing initial stack pointer and all interrupt handler addresses.
Ratio of signal propagation velocity in a cable to the speed of light; typically 0.66 to 0.85.
A hardware description language for designing and simulating digital circuits.
A hardware description language for designing and simulating digital circuits.
Ratio of via depth to diameter; standard mechanical drills are limited to about 10:1.
Row of closely spaced vias along a trace or boundary, confining fields and improving isolation between sections.
PCB technique placing a via directly in a component pad, requiring via fill and planarization to prevent solder wicking.
Voltage Input High — the minimum voltage a logic input recognizes as a valid HIGH.
Voltage Input Low — the maximum voltage a logic input recognizes as a valid LOW.
The condition in a negative-feedback op-amp circuit where both inputs are at effectively the same voltage.
Memory management scheme where each process sees its own address space, with the MMU translating virtual addresses to physical pages. Enables process isolation and memory protection.
Vector Network Analyzer — instrument measuring magnitude and phase of S-parameters for impedance and filter characterization.
Voltage Output High — the minimum voltage a logic output guarantees when driving a logic HIGH.
Voltage Output Low — the maximum voltage a logic output guarantees when driving a logic LOW.
C qualifier preventing the compiler from caching a variable in registers; required for ISR-shared and hardware-mapped variables but does not provide atomicity.
SI unit of electric potential difference.
The change in a component's value with applied voltage.
A network (typically two resistors in series) that produces an output voltage proportional to the input voltage.
The standard BJT biasing topology using a resistor divider to set base voltage and an emitter resistor to stabilize collector current.
The available voltage range for signal swing between supply rails and saturation/cutoff limits.
Technique for locating shorts on a PCB by injecting current through the short and measuring the voltage gradient to find the fault location.
A circuit producing a precise, stable voltage used as a comparison standard in regulators, ADCs, and measurement.
Processor architecture using a single bus for both instructions and data. Simple but limited by bus contention — the CPU cannot fetch an instruction and access data simultaneously.
Voltage Standing Wave Ratio — ratio of voltage maximum to minimum on a transmission line indicating match quality.
Circle on the Smith chart representing all impedances with the same VSWR.
Very low-frequency phase variation (below 10 Hz) in a clock or data signal, distinct from jitter.
A timer that resets a system if it fails to complete a sequence within bounded time.
Data breakpoint that halts the CPU when a specific memory address is read or written; uses DWT hardware.
SI unit of power.
Unit of energy.
Mass soldering process where a PCB passes over a standing wave of molten solder, connecting all through-hole joints at once.
Metallic pipe structure for guiding electromagnetic waves at microwave and millimeter-wave frequencies.
Variable time-frequency transform with good time resolution at high frequencies and good frequency resolution at low.
Worst-Case Execution Time — the maximum time a code path can take including all delays; the only time that matters for real-time guarantees.
TI online design tool that generates customized power supply schematics and component selections from user requirements.
A four-resistor bridge circuit used for precise measurement of resistance changes, commonly used with strain gauges and RTDs.
Technique for measuring antenna radiation efficiency by comparing impedance with and without a conductive enclosure.
Modified current mirror using an emitter resistor on the output transistor to produce a much smaller reference current.
Gently flexing cables, pressing connectors, or tapping components while monitoring for intermittent behavior to localize mechanical connection faults.
Broadband power divider using quarter-wave lines and termination resistor; good isolation and matched ports.
Three-transistor current mirror that cancels base-current error, giving higher output impedance than a simple mirror.
FIR filter design method: truncate the ideal sinc impulse response to finite length and apply a window function to control sidelobes.
Taper applied to finite-length signal blocks to reduce spectral leakage at the cost of frequency resolution.
The moving contact in a potentiometer that slides along the resistive element, creating a variable voltage divider.
Precision resistor made by winding resistance wire on a form.
I2S signal toggling at the sample rate to indicate left or right audio channel; also called LRCK.
Tolerance method assuming all components are simultaneously at their extreme values to guarantee circuit operation.
Class II ceramic dielectric rated for -55°C to +85°C with ±15% capacitance variation over temperature.
Class II ceramic dielectric rated for -55°C to +125°C with ±15% capacitance variation over temperature.
A logic gate that outputs 1 when inputs differ.
Class III ceramic dielectric with very high capacitance density but terrible stability: +22% / -82% over temperature range.
Directional antenna with driven element, reflector, and directors providing high gain.
Embedded Linux build framework producing custom distributions with layer-based configuration and long-term maintenance support.
A diode designed to operate in reverse breakdown at a specific voltage, used for voltage references and simple regulators.
A simple voltage regulator consisting of a Zener diode fed through a current-limiting resistor.
Modern embedded RTOS with device tree, driver framework, networking, and Bluetooth support.
A frequency in a transfer function that contributes +20 dB/decade gain and up to +90° of phase advance.
Receiver downconverting directly to baseband; eliminates image problems but introduces DC offset.
Simplest DAC reconstruction holding each sample value until the next; produces staircase with sinc-shaped frequency response.
Appending zeros to a signal block before FFT to interpolate the spectrum; improves display smoothness but not true resolution.
